summary: EBOV tropism toward antigen-presenting cells is thought to play an important role in viral pathogenesis. EBOV productively infects APCs, including monocytes, macrophages, and dendritic cells (DCs), in vitro (3–9) and tissue sections from EBOV-infected humans and nonhuman primates contain APCs positive for EBOV antigen/nucleic acid. additional host factors have also been implicated as regulating entry. this includes components of the homotypic fusion and vacuole protein-sorting complex. s are nonpermissive for EBOV GP-mediated entry unless differentiated into macrophage-like cells. cells were cultured in DMEM supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS) and 1% l-glutamine. plasmids used in transfections included pcDNA BLA-VP40, which expresses a -lactamase-Zaire EBOV VP40 chimera. monocytes were plated (0.7 106 to 1 106 cells/ml) in DC medium. they were plated with 100 U of penicillin/ml, 10 g of streptomycin/ml. the 293T cell spent supernatant was layered over 10 ml of 20% sucrose in NTE buffer (100 mM NaCl, 20 mM Tris-hydrochloride [pH 7.5] and 1 mM EDTA [EDTA]) the VLPs were finally resuspended in a total of 150 l of NTE and stored on ice at 4°C. titers were determined using an agarose plaque assay. agarose cells were plated in six-well plates to 90 to 100% confluence. fivefold dilutions of stock virus were prepared. d (spinoculated) at 1,850 rpm for 45 min at 4°C before incubation at 37°C in 2% RPMI medium for the indicated times. an LSR II (BD Bioscience) flow cytometer equipped with a violet laser was used to excite the CCF2-AM substrate. events were assayed for green and blue fluorescence after sorting for live cells. day 3 spent supernatants from infected and noninfected control cells were analyzed. total RNA was harvested using Tri-Reagent, which was added to each well containing (infected) cells. cDNA was extracted from the aqueous phase of the Tri-Reagent (Sigma-Aldrich) samples using an RNeasy micro kit. EBOV GP-mediated entry was restricted in human (Fig. 1B and D) and mouse (Fig. 1C) monocytes. monocytes are typically differentiated into immature DCs by incubation with GM-CSF plus IL-4 (54) for 5 to 7 days. at 18 h after cytokine treatment, 10% of the monocytes permitted entry. increased EBOV GP-mediated entry efficiency was associated with increased duration of cytokine exposure. EBOV infection of monocytes is delayed compared to DCs. a recombinant EBOV expressing GFP was used to test infection efficiency in monocytes and DCs. at 48 h postinfection, there was an 3-fold difference in the number of GFP+ monocytes and DCs. this difference was no longer apparent by 72 h postinfection.
